Comments_List: Learned about creole and contact languages from many different perspectives. First, we discussed the historical context of West Africa, the slave trade, and the Caribbean. Then, we discussed the typology (or lack thereof) of creole languages as well as the theory of hybrid grammars. Finally, we examined the syntax of Atlantic creole languages and how it originated in the syntaxes of the superstrate and substrate. Overall, very interesting course!

Learned how to get the gist of long linguistics papers even when I did not understand every detail of the syntax presented in them, learned recombination theory and the socio-historical nature of the designation "creole"

Learned about creoles and hybrid grammars
Competition and selection of linguistic features in the process of language emergence
Recombination as an underlying linguistic mechanism; re-assessment of creolisation theories; analysis within a generative syntax framework

I learned the process of creole-formation and change, which can be projected onto all language formation and change.  I learned the history of Atlantic creoles and the leading theories of creole formation, including Prof. Aboh's leading theory.
I really liked how we got to discuss history, syntactic theory, change, and specific linguistic properties of the Atlantic creoles, all in one course.

Strengths: Interesting lectures, flexible writing topics
Weaknesses: Lecture slides and readings are very similar, so it's hard to understand one if you don't understand the other

This was such an interesting and wonderful course that approached traditional theories of language contact from a very different viewpoint; Enochs recombination analysis is really on to something that could redefine the study of language contact and the entire field of Linguistics as a whole

This course was the best linguistics course I have taken at my time here because it helped me discover a passion for language-change. However, I felt as though the course materials ran out about two weeks before the end of classes so that those last two weeks were not as engaging as the beginning of the semester.
Yes definitely, but requires background in linguistics.
Yes, I would recommend it to anyone with any familiarity with linguistics because it puts forth a whole new way to see linguistics
Enoch probably isnt coming back, if you ever have a chance to take a class with him, you should definitely do it. It was amazing to take this class. Enoch was great and so helpful!!
This class will change your perspective on languages, so yes, absolutely take this class.
